script: Don't worry, it's just a pack of wolves.
Come on, we're almost rid of it.
Come on, help me bury it.
What if someone digs it up?
May God have mercy on his soul.
BOY: He's going to his dad's factory.
BOY 2: Parrish wants his daddy now.
Now, I've been working on this for almost a year.
And I got an appointment this afternoon with your father to show him this.
If I can get Wilt Chamberlain to wear 'em, I predict there'll be a pair of those in every closet in America.
That's gonna be the height of fashion.
I've told you. This factory isn't a playground.
Dad, can I have a ride home?
Oh, Alan, is Billy Jessup picking on you again?
Son, you're gonna have to face him sooner or later.
If you're afraid of something, you've got to stand and face it.
Carl, you should know better than to let the boy play in here.
Oh, uh, what was it you wanted to show me?
Just because you're a Parrish doesn't mean you can hang around with my girlfriend.
MR. PARRISH: ...hard work, determination, a cheerful outlook.
Attributes that have exemplified the Brantford spirit since our forefathers first settled this town.
Despite the harshness of our native clime and the granite of our soil, we have-- Prospects.
I knew the whole damn thing this morning.
I told your father what you told me this afternoon, that it wasn't just Billy Jessup.
if I'd known that, Alan, I wouldn't have-- It's okay, Dad.
But I want you to know how proud I am of you.
I mean, you faced them, even though you were outnumbered.
since you took it like a man, your mother and I have decided that you're ready to go to The Cliffside School for Boys.
You don't want me living here anymore?
MRS. PARRISH: Alan-- It's always been the plan that you'd go to Cliffside when you were ready.
I mean, Parrishes have been going to Cliffside, uh, ever since the 1700s.
Even your Uncle Skylar went there.
MR. PARRISH: It's the main dormitory.
Kids are on my case here because I'm a Parrish.
Just wait till I'm living in a building named after me.
It was named after my father.
Good. Why don't you live in it?
I wouldn't be who I am today if it weren't for my years there.
Maybe I don't want to be who you are.
Maybe I don't even want to be a Parrish.
You won't be. Not till you start acting like one.
I guess I'm not ready for Cliffside then!
We're taking you there next Sunday!
And I don't want to hear another word about it!
You won't! I'm never talking to you again!
Nothing. Just-- What are you doing here?
I was going over to Billy's to get it myself.
I told Billy to stop picking on you.
You shouldn't have wasted your breath.
But we've got to talk about this some other time.
I found this really weird game in the factory.
A game for those who seek to find a way to leave their world behind.
You roll the dice to move your token.
The first player to reach the end wins. Want to play?
I quit playing board games five years ago.
It's got to be magnetized or something.
At night they fly, you better run, these winged things are not much fun.
What do you mean the game thinks?
ALAN: In the jungle you must wait, until the dice read five or eight.
In the jungle you must wait.
WOMAN: I think a bed and breakfast is just what this town needs.
NORA: Well, it was pretty hard to pass up, especially full of furniture.
I keep forgetting how big this place is.
Judy, Peter, come look at this!
I'm gonna put a reception area right over here.
A bar over here in the parlor.
I'm sure you and your kids are gonna be very happy here.
He and his wife passed away just last winter.
What do you think, young man?
Peter hasn't spoken a word since it happened.
We barely even knew our parents.
Skiing in St Moritz, gambling in Monte Carlo.
We didn't even know if they loved us.
But when the sheik's yacht went down, well...
they managed to write us a really beautiful goodbye note that was found floating in a champagne bottle amongst the debris.
It was a car crash in Canada.
So you'll send me those escrow papers?
Oh, I'll have to get a locksmith out for this one.
Peter, pick up your toys, please.
Peter, take this suitcase up to the attic.
Then we can all have ice cream.
He said it looked like that.
Some kid said she saw a bunch of those back in the '60s.
But we don't get bats like that in New England.
Well, whatever it was, it's gone now.
Bats aren't what I'd worry about in this house, anyways.
Well, personally, I wouldn't want to live in a house where someone was murdered.
I say his father did it.
There's a thousand and one places he could have hid the body in this house.
Especially if he chopped it up first.
You kids don't want to be late for your first day of school.
Not a bat in sight, ma'am.
There's nothing to be afraid of in this house!
I can't believe I have to see your principal after your first day.
Now, let's just try to relax and finish our dinner and talk about something else.
Well, we found out why you got this house so cheap.
Twenty-six years ago, a kid named Alan Parrish used to live here.
Then one day, he just disappeared 'cause his parents chopped him up in little pieces and hid him in the walls.
Okay. That's it. I am sick and tired of your lies, young lady.
Fine. There's nowhere to go in this stupid town anyway.
But just for your information, that wasn't a lie.
Did you hear anything a little while ago?
Do you miss Mom and Dad?
If you don't cut that out, they're gonna send you to a shrink.
Where do you think they're gonna send you if you don't start talking?
If I get held up at the permit office, I'll give you a call.
School bus should be here any minute.
You guys still have your house keys?
Are you guys listening to me?
Maybe I should wait with you till the bus comes.
Did your parents used to put you on the bus?
A game for those who seek to find a way to leave their world behind.
You roll the dice to move your token.
The first player to reach the end wins.
It's got to be microchips or something.
JUDY: A tiny bite can make you itch, make you sneeze, make you twitch.
PETER: This will not be an easy mission.
I bet those monkeys came from the game.
Do not begin unless you intend to finish.
The exciting consequences of the game will vanish only when a player has reached Jumanji and called out its name.
The instructions say if we finish the game it will all go away.
We better do it, or Aunt Nora's gonna pitch a fit.
We should just get through it quickly.
I mean, there's no skill involved.
I don't like the sound of that.
Somebody roll a five or an eight?
It's me, Alan, Mom and Dad.
This house has been empty for years.
WOMAN: I said red fur, long tail.
Get down off of my car, please.
And get up on the sidewalk.
You left it in the other Tarzan outfit, right?
He was in the Peace Corps.
CARL: Does he always dress like that?
JUDY: Well, yeah. He's a vegetarian.
Is--? Is he all right upstairs?
He suffered a head injury a few months ago.
My dad used to make shoes here.
They were the best shoes in New England.
Do you know what happened to this shoe factory?
Like everything else in this town.
Why would they close Parrish Shoes?
Sam put everything he had into trying to find him.
After a while, he stopped coming to work.
I don't think anybody loved his boy more than Sam did.
I see them now and then.
They were in the Middle East negotiating peace-- Our dad was in advertising.
Listen, I know you're upset and all, but I kind of feel we should finish the game.
We? Why do you need me?
Well...just in case any other scary stuff comes out.
Plus there's a lion in my aunt's bedroom.
What am I supposed to do about that?
I hope she's not allergic to cats.
MAN: Larry! We need the wheels.
No. It looks like another one of those weird bites.
Yeah, it's another one, all right.
What came out of the game before me?
Um, there was a lion, a bunch of monkeys, and, um...
We'll stay low. He can't get through there too far, okay?
Hey! He can't get us in here.
He can't get through the glass.
Either one of you know how to drive?
My dad used to let me back the car down the driveway...
Keep that thing away from me.
When are you going to help us play?
We've got to hurry. Our aunt's going to be home soon.
You can inform her that she's the ex-owner of this house.
'Cause I hope you realize with my parents gone, this home belongs to me.
What do you think those monkeys are gonna do to the ecosystem around here?
Of this tropic port What happened to you?
You shave with a piece of glass?
How about Peter and I play, and you just sort of watch?
So if you're not gonna help us, what are you gonna do?
I don't know. Pretty much take up where I left off.
I wonder if Mrs. Niedermeyer's still teaching sixth grade?
Come on, Judy, he's not going to help us. He's afraid.
Let's go set it up in the living room.
No, you have no idea what you're getting yourself into.
Whatever it is, we'll handle it by ourselves.
You think the monkeys, mosquitoes and lions are bad?
I've seen things you've only seen in your nightmares.
There are things that hunt you in the night.
Then something screams, then you hear them eat, and you hope to God that you're not dessert.
You don't even know what afraid is.
You will not last five minutes without me.
Dad used to pull it on me all the time.
Yeah, I rolled first, and then Peter twice 'cause he got doubles, and now it's my turn again.
Two of those pieces are yours, right?
You're playing the game I started in 1969.
This is where she used to live.
This place gives me the creeps.
We used to play on this porch.
I knew she still wouldn't live here.
Probably married Billy Jessup, and they're living in a trailer park.
Maybe she'll know where Sarah went.
Of course she'll know where Sarah went. She's a psychic.
I remember the porch being a lot bigger, though.
No, we're just trying to find someone.
Well, Madam Serena can't see anyone right now.
Well, maybe you can help us.
We're looking for someone who used to live here.
No, I've lived here my whole life.
Well, then you must know Sarah Whittle.
What do you want with Sarah Whittle?
No, I-I don't go by that name anymore.
Twenty-six years ago, you played a game with a little boy down the street.
I was that little boy, Sarah.
Leave a message, and the doctor will call you back at his earliest convenience.
Listen, if you could call me back as soon as you can, I think I need to have my dosage checked.
That event we've been discussing for a long time now, the one that didn't really happen?
Oh, boy, I'm having an episode here today with the little boy that didn't really disappear.
I'm sitting in his living room, drinking lemonade.
If you could call me, I'd really, really be interested in your interpretation.
Call me back 10 minutes before the hour.
Alan, I have spent over 2000 hours in therapy convincing myself that this doesn't exist.
What happened to you was so awful I made up that whole thing...
Your father murdered you and chopped you up into pieces.
My father could barely hug me, let alone cut me into little pieces.
Twenty-six years ago, we started playing a little game.
And now we're all gonna sit down, and we're gonna finish it.
Just give me the dice, and you can go home.
It's law of the jungle, Sarah.
SARAH: When I think of all the energy I spent visualizing you as a radiant spirit.
They grow much faster than bamboo.
Take care or they'll come after you.
SARAH: Oh, God. Tell me this isn't happening.
Stay away from the walls, don't touch anything.
And definitely stay away from the pods.
PETER: Get it off me. Get it off me!
Where in heaven's name have you been?
We've got an animal-control situation on our hands here.
You've got to get Stan and Willy on it.
I'm heading over to the old Parrish place to check out a suspicious character, over.
I should have been a fireman.
Ooh! Get your hands off me!
The game is not over yet, Sarah.
You are not in the jungle anymore.
You don't treat people like this!
Last time I played this game, it ruined my life.
In the jungle you must wait till the dice read five or eight.
I was a little girl, Alan.
And a bunch of bats surrounded me and chased me down the street.
But if we finish the game, it'll all go away.
What if I get stuck in the game?
Oh, I knew this was going to be a bad day.
We just have to keep our heads.
A hunter from the darkest wilds makes you feel just like a child.
Come back and face me like a man!
Drop your gun and get your hands in the air.
So even if Alan gets out of this situation, the same thing's going to happen over and over again.
When you carry around so much repressed anger, it attracts a lot of negative energy, and things happen, like ending up in the jungle.
You might have told us there was a man there that hunts people.
Is he the reason you didn't want to play?
You didn't want to play either?
What's the deal with you and this guy?
He's a hunter. He kills things.
And right now he wants to hunt and kill me, okay?
I don't know. Everything about me he finds offensive.
You'd think it would be a waste of time.
Maybe he needs something for his wall.
Have you thought about sitting and talking about your differences?
Don't ever call me crazy, Alan. Ever.
Because everyone in this town has called me crazy ever since I told the cops you were sucked into a board game.
SARAH: ...girl who saw Alan Parrish murdered?
Do you think anybody showed up at my 14th birthday party?
ALAN: Oh, ho. What are you, an owl?
Madam Serena, why don't you dig in the lower reaches...
ALAN: ...find the memory of your boyfriend, Billy?
The little kid who used to steal your bicycle?
No, the big kid who probably...
JUDY: Don't be fooled, it isn't thunder.
Staying put would be a blunder.
I know you are, but what am I?
Why didn't you grab the game, Peter?
What can I do for you?
I want a gross of these.
You know they stopped making these in 1903?
Then I shall need a replacement weapon.
And you'll have to fill out these.
Or I could fill these out.
Now, anyone asks, you didn't get this here.
You're not a postal worker, are you?
JUDY: I can't believe you did that! That was so cool.
You gave me chills! Oh, my God!
Come on, give me the game.
Every time there's trouble, I run into you.
Me? I don't know what you're talking about.
I'm taking you in for questioning.
I'm not going anywhere. Oh! Ah!
I thought you said he's your uncle.
Remember you said you'd never abandon your friends?
I suggest you all go home now.
Now how are we supposed to finish the game?
I thought I could end the game myself. I was 10 spaces away.
A law of Jumanji hadn't been broken.
You will slip back even more than your token.
No! I tried to drop the dice so they'd land on 12.
You've got to get the National Guard down here now.
All right. What is this about?
But you wouldn't believe me even if I told you, Carl.
Wait a minute, wait a minute.
How did you know my name is Carl?
I know a lot more than that.
I know you used to work on the stamping line at Parrish Shoes.
They used to call you Sole Man.
I was in there too, man, till old man Parrish fired me.
And I had something-- I could have turned this whole town around.
I know it doesn't mean much after 26 years, but I'm sorry.
Well, apparently there's a sale, honey. Whoa!
You just saw three monkeys go by on a motorcycle, didn't you?
Well, maybe we can bail him out with a check.
Tell that sniveling coward from me, if he wants-- VAN PELT: Hey!
When Alan hears of your predicament, he'll come.
You know, he doesn't even know I'm here, so your plan's ruined.
Don't move, or I'll blow your brains out!
If you let me go, I can stop all this.
It sounds like The Twilight Zone, but it's true, all right?
You've got to help me on this.
I know I'm going to regret this.
Now what are we going to do?
This is something I have to do!
Hostage situation at Sir Sav-a-lot involving woman and two children.
Sounds like the armed perpetrator in the pith helmet you reported earlier.
I don't know what's left of it.
People in this town are going loopy.
No, no, no. It's all right.
Come on, get out of here.
I could've shot you at any moment.
There it is, there it is.
He should be here any moment.
So remember, circumstances are never ever out of your control.

WOMAN: To update on the extraordinary events unfolding in Brantford, New Hampshire, where 98 people have been hospitalized with symptoms ranging from inexplicable fevers and rashes to violent seizures.
Local resources have been strained to the breaking point...
...asking anyone experiencing such symptoms to dial 911.
What? We don't have time for this, okay?
I know, but he's a kid, and he was trying to help.
I warned you about this, Peter.
But, no, you wanted to play the game.
Come on! Keep your chin up!
Crying never helped anybody do anything, okay?
If you have a problem, you face it like a man.
Twenty-six years buried in the deepest, darkest jungle, and I still became my father.
It's okay. Come here, I'm sorry.
We're going to have you turned back into your old self in no time flat, because we're going in here, and together, we're going to sit down, we're going to finish that game, no matter...
Suddenly I feel right at home.
I'm heading to the Parrish place. I need backup.
Oh, can I have a ride home?
I'll explain it all on the way.
We got to get to that house.
No. I grew up in this.
It's out there that scares me.
If you roll a 12, you win.
Every month at the quarter moon, there'll be a monsoon in your lagoon.
Well, a little rain never hurt anybody.
Yeah, but a lot can kill you.
Uh, ma'am? Step back and let me handle this, please.
They probably left the TV on too loud.
I always wanted to do this.
Alan, you wrestled an alligator for me.
Alligators don't have that little fringe on the hind leg.
Colonel Mustard in the library with a wrench.
Beware the ground on which you stand.
The floor is quicker than the sand.
Stop giving me things that come apart!
JUDY: There is a lesson-- All right.
There is a lesson you will learn...
Sometimes you must go back a turn.
Sarah and I would like to get out of the floor, so it's your turn, Peter.
I thought I'd lost you again.
Thanks for sticking around this time.
You don't go Whah! for nothing.
My dad kept an axe in the woodshed. Go get it!
There's-- There's a-- Aunt Nora, it's me, Peter.
Sorry. I can't talk right now.
You can finish if you roll a seven!
Put the dice in your mouth.
SARAH: Judy, bring the game. Hurry!
You're almost there with much at stake.
Now the ground begins to quake.
I...wish Mom and Dad were here.
ALAN: Our only chance is if we finish the game!
No! I won't let you go!
End of the line, Sonny Jim.
you should always face what you're afraid of.
You're finally acting like a man.
I've only been gone five minutes.
It seems like a lot longer to me.
Hey, I thought you told me, you were never going to talk to me again.
Look, you don't have to go to Cliffside if you don't want to.
Hey, I've got to get going.
Back in 196-- I mean, today in the factory, it wasn't Carl Bentley's fault.
I put the shoe on the conveyer belt.
I'm glad you told me, son.
I'm starting to forget what it's like to be a grownup.
That's okay. As long as we don't forget each other.
Alan, there's something I've been wanting to do.
And I'd better do it before I feel too much like a kid.
They probably don't teach driver training in the sixth grade, huh?
Listen, Dad, I've got to run.
Merry Christmas. We'll pick you up tomorrow at the airport.
It'll be the best Christmas gift. Bye-bye. Bye-bye.
Jim, glad you could make it.
A guess. A guess, of course.
Kids, say hi to Mr. and Mrs. Parrish.
You're just like we remembered you.
I feel like we know so much about them, because, you know-- SARAH: You've told Al about them.
I'll go and get the presents.
Well, actually, Martha and I were thinking of taking a little skiing holiday up in the Canadian Rockies.
We need you to get that marketing done on the new line pronto.
You know, I can probably start next week.
Let me introduce you to the folks around here you'll be working with, okay?
